timeline.bodyText:
This Optional<T>.get() can throw NPE.
If we really, really, really know it won't be null, let's use getOrElse(IllegalStateException::new).
The main reason we introduced Optional<User> was to replace nullable getAccount() call. The trouble with getAccount() was that callers were liberally assuming valid return value. Since the code was then full of if (account == null) { some ad-hoc remediation } workarounds, this assumption was not really holding up. My suspicion was that we were experiencing many edge cases of NPEs and were trying to patch them in some simple way.
Hence the Optional<T> which provides more explicit and harder to ignore API.
Having said all of the above, I think that the best idea would be to pass User instead of Optional<User> and just make sure that if the user dependency is not available, we never get here in the first place. This way we don't need to handle special case.
